reviewText:
Possibly the best and the most enjoyable non-RPG Star Wars game made. Although mainly a FPS almost identical to the Battlefield series in the terms of the amount of reserves, but in this game there are also dogfight space battles and more, and also a more tactical game mode where you are to conquer the galaxy.
The campaign is of a good length and covers the II-IV parts of the series, however you are able to play on any other planet that was mentioned in the series. The multiplayer is really fun, especially the Mos Eisley map where there is an option that every player is a special character. These include all the famous characters such as jedis, which are more powerful then the ordinary footsoldiers you get to play as in the singleplayer campaign. There are also bunch of other mods for these custom missions. The game is very fun to play with your friends, however the PC version does not include split-screen which is a shame, so you and your friends will have to play it online.
The graphics are still good, although aged, unless you are a whiney Crysis kid who values the game by its visual aspects only. If that is the case then this game might not be for you. However if you are not and decide to get it, you will be suprised that the game still looks nice, but that isn't why you bought it then.
Some people might also find the game hard to play, since it can get pretty difficult, especially in the later levels.

The bad parts of the game is that there are some issues with newer versions of Windows, and that you might wait a couple of days before getting your CD key, since Disney shut down the magnificient LucasArts and we all know what Disney is about now : $$$
The story is linear, and so are the objectives that are mainly to capture an objective or to defend a position while killing the enemy, but the combat is fun and the missions are interesting.
Also the bad part is that there arent plenty of multiplayer servers (currently about 50) so you don't have quite a big choce, and most of them are filled with veterans who will dominate you over and over again, but when you are playing with friends you will probably host the game.

I have played this game since it came out, and I have finished the singleplayer many times. If you have the amount of money it costs and you don't mind slightly outdated graphics, then immediately purchase this game and you won't regret it.

reviewText: Back in the days of the PS2, this was the single greatest game I owned. When I found it on steam, I quickly bought it. Half expecting a poor port, I cautiously started the game up. reviewText:
Looked at the sky during lightsaber combo to see dead players fly. 10/10

In all seriousness, if you wanted to stage large-scale battles at basically any point in the Star Wars universe (even in space),or play a game of galactic chess against another person in Galactic Conquest, then by all means GET THE GAME!

If not, then I do not wish to continue with this review because that is just sad; not wanting to stage battles of epic proportions between Ewoks and Scout Troopers on Endor.

I give this game a rating of Health Sword/Good Times Lance. Is rly gud.

As for online multiplayer (such a shame to have seen it go), there is still the possibility of using network programs, like Hamachi, to play with your friends.

reviewText: READ THIS REVIEW IF HESITANT ON BUYING THIS GAME!\nIf you are a huge Star Wars fan then you need to buy this game! I played this game on the Playstation 2 when it came out and it was part of my childhood. I was never really dissapointed with this game, the Campaign was very enjoyable (and a bit challenging at times) but a little short and the maps are very fun to play on and has huge variety (From the snowy landscape of Hoth to the murky Swaps of Dagobah). My favorite is the Galactic conquest mode where you have to capture planets to win and each of the planets are worth a certain amount of points and there is also Instant action which is quick matches. I don't know why people are complaining about the online multiplayer, yes it was run by GAMESPY, and yes they did shutdown; but there is still DEDICATED SERVERS that you can go and play on if you want multiplayer action, and you can still HOST games and have friends join your server; you can also use Gameranger and join through there as well. The space combat is just how i remembered it fun and very unique in there being different ways to approach and destroy your opponent's ship. This game is a masterpiece of its time and deserves to be in your game library (hopefully with hours played on it :] ) and as always MAY THE FORCE BE WITH YOU!

reviewText: Great game, for more than just the nostalgia, even if you have never played before I'd recommend it. Story mode in a nut shell it's the story of the 501st clone legion and their part in the Star Wars universe from the mid clone wars to the battle on Hoth with awesome little journal entries from a surviving member before and after each stage. Along with story mode there are stand alone levels on various modes and galactic conquest where you pick a side and try to either conqure or free the galaxy. It's sad that the GameSpy servers are going down but I know I'm going to still be playing what is an overall fun game (already been doing so since I was about 12) and I can't wait for the next one.

reviewText:
Star Wars Battlefront II is a fantastic game despite its rather old age. A greatly voice acted and narrated campaign is just the icing on this Star Wars themed cake which is accompanied by an assortment different singleplayer game modes including Galactic Conquest, which is reminiscent of Star Wars Empire at War, another great game.

The AI is rather dumb, but that's to be expected with a game that is a decade old; the campaign still manages to challenge you at times, especially if you don't know what to expect.

Unfortunately, the multiplayer servers hosted by Gamespy have been shut down recently, but third party programs such as Game Ranger allows you to experience the still living-breathing online scene, which is made even better if you have a group of friends to screw around with.

The wide array of vehicles, special units, and heroes makes Battlefront a fun game to play to this day, and I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a fun Star Wars shooter.

reviewText:
In a Nutshell Battlefront 2 is an old, yet sweet game. Definitely worth playing 10 years later with no online. (Psst, even if the online isn’t available, you can still find alternative methods, google it.)
It controls well with a few tweaks, and switching between 3rd and 1st person gameplay is smooth and useful. Shooting people is satisfying, but the aiming in 3rd person is a wee bit off. Vehicles are a little wonky too, but it’s a lot of fun blowing people up with them, and the classes are varied and fun.

Be wary about buying though, as the online is discontinued, and despite being able to revive it with external programs, the community isn’t exactly large, and you have the new battlefront coming out by EA, so there is that too. Despite that, playing offline is still a ton of fun

reviewText:
Upsides/Overview

I played hours upon hours of this game years ago on my xbox original. Without this game, the genre of first person shooter would be very different indeed. Not only does this game offer some of the best team based strategic play I've seen to date, but this game also did it around a time when battles on a large scale were not something to be brushed off as ordinary. The game is very fun, even if you're not a hardcore star wars fan. Multiplayer was unfortunately taken down as Gamespy closed, but not to worry, gameranger has servers online as I'm typing this out, and gameranger is free. You will experience lag on gameranger servers, but if you have the proper bandwidth and hardware to support your own server, you will have the chance to play a game that becomes exponentially more fun the more people you play with.

+Awesome Space Battles, Land Battles, and Land Battles in Space
+Vehicle gameplay
+Class counter-gameplay/Vehicle counter-gameplay
+Capture the Point (Conquest) style
+Plenty of awesome mods
+Very solid gunplay
+Galactic Conquest, a long term war to rule the galaxy (Evil laughing)
+Choice between CIS (Droids), Republic (Clones), The Empire (Stormtroopers), and The Rebels (Watch the damn movie)
+Upgrade/Mastery system on guns/classes
+A.I. is pretty great for space battles
+Multiplayer is still a thing
+I could go on for a long time

Downsides/Conclusion

-This game is old, and looks old
-You will experience bugs if you play long enough
-A.I. are often easy even on the hardest difficulty for a person who has gotten used to the game (Doesn't take very long)
-Overpowered advanced classes on some factions, underpowered on other factions, (The Bothan Spy really doesn't compare to the Empirial Officer, Shock Trooper way better than Wookies. Jet pack trooper and Clone Commander are really bad in comparison to the MagnaGaurd and Droideka and I could go on.)
-Playing by yourself isn't very fun after a while
-Playing with friends can easily be laggy
-Steam doesn't always have this game on sale for 5 bucks (If it is on sale for 5 or really anything but ten, get it, it's worth way more than 5, but because of its age it really doesn't need to be priced at 10.)
-Upcoming Battlefront 3 game may sweep the floor with this one, not neccesarily a bad thing if Battlefront 3 is actually good, but it is a bad thing if it sweeps this game under the rug for no reason.

In conclusion, you really need to get this game, and get your friends to get this game. If you haven't played it yet you need to. If you have played it already but don't have it, get it. If you have played it and have it, get another copy for your friend. If you don't have any friends and have it, get another copy and make a friend today.

reviewText:
Star Wars - Battlefront II is a third person shooter by LucasArts that puts you in the shoes of a common trooper or a droid while you reenact the greatest battle of the six Star Wars movies.You can play as the armies of the Republic, the CIS, the Empire and the Rebels, since the game covers both the Clone Wars and the Galactic Civil War eras from the Star Wars canon.
Battlefront II spots a single player campaign revolving around a legion of elite clone soldiers, the 501st, as they serve the Republic during the Clone Wars during the last days of the democracy to later become one of the most feared army of the new Galactic Empire. The campaign takes place in several maps also available in multiplayer, but also tasks the player to complete several kinds of objective (like capturing a command post, destroying a target or defeat an enemy hero), so playing through the various missions feels like an unique experience and worth of a try.
Battlefront II also introduces new maps where space battle take place: you can play as either a pilot or a marine from your faction, grab a ship (which can be either a heavy bombardier or a fast fighter) and try to severely damage the enemy fleet by either destroying its fighters or cripple its main ship either from the outside or the inside. While space battles always follow a strick formula with little room for alternative strategies, they are a welcome addition nevertheless.
One of the major improvement from the original game in the sequel is about the hero units: while in Battlefront they weren't playable, the second game allows you to take direct control of them, albeit for a short time (which you can increase by killing enemies). You can play as both Sith and Jedi and scoundrels and bounty hunters from the two eras, each with his/her own weapons and powers.
Another single player mode you can access in Battlefront II is the galactic conquest scenario: after choosing one of the four faction you are tasked to bring it to victory over its rival army and take absolute control of the galaxy. You have to move your army on a map of the galaxy and plan your attacks carefully. Winning confrontations grants you credits that can be used to purchase bonuses that can be activated for a single battle to enhance your armies (the bacta tanks perk will give your soldiers regenerating health, for instance).
The multiplayer mode returns in Battlefront II in full force, offering several traditional game modes like capture the flag or control point captures or hunt on a pletora of new maps. It's also worth mentioning that the game has a very dedicated modding community always redy to develop new maps from different eras of the Star Wars canon (the Old Republic, for instance) or add new heroic or normal units per factions.
Star Wars - Battlefront II is often labelled as one of the best games with a Star Wars license and I tend to agree, due to the very interesting and catchy gameplay and the excellent use of the series' canonic materials

HOW TO FIX MISSIOM STARTUP CRASH:

1. Go to your start menu (on your computer), and click Control Panel".

2.Click on "Hardware and Sound".

3. Click on "Sound".

4. Go to the tab that says "Recording".

5. Right click in a white space within the window and make sure that "Show Disabled Devices" is checked.

6. Enable "Stereo Mix"
date:
and click apply.

7. Enjoy your crash-free battlefront :)

reviewText:
Alright, my hours aren't very much on PC, but if my PS2 hours showed, it would be in the hundreds. This was (and still always will be) my favorite game of all time. This was my weekend with friends, this was my down time after school, this was the only game I would play for hours on end.

PROS:
-Amazing gameplay for an older game with large battles and a great design.
-Many well balanced classes to chose from (plus many more Hero/Villain characters).
-Large, well designed maps.
-Various gamemodes for a different experience every time (e.g. Hunt, CTF, Conquest, Assault, etc).
-Great vehicular combat and variety.

CONS:
-Graphics are old (but really who cares?)
-AI is a little stupid at times
-EWOKS! DARN YOU AND YOUR ROCKS!

This game I recommend for anyone looking for a good Star Wars battle experience.

11/10

reviewText: Just going to start off in saying this, THIS, is one of the best games. Ever. With more replay value than over 10 games, There are hundreds of thousands of mods with completely new campaigns, maps, new skins, new characters completely including Jedi and Sith, soundtracks, Galactic Conquests, general patches that give fake console; a modding work of art and free camrea on top of being able to select any campaign mission without playing them. Did I mention there's still online via GameRanger and GameMaster? Only thousands of hours in that alone and something I have. I'm not biased or alone in saying this either. I have SEVERAL friends with hours that rank up in the thousands, one with over 20k! You could write a book on the strategy that goes into it as well and stands tall even after 11 years as one of the best gamer ever. Then we got Hero Assault; going past the average player who thinks it's a fun little side game mode, it's VERY complex with literally hundreds (I am being completely serious) of different strategies and a lot of different tricks and game laws for Hero Assault such as null; where you stop an enemy dash cold with percise timing. In the high level matches, you find yourself making about 20 moves a second and have to predict your opponents actions it's so complex and fun.

reviewText:
Star Wars - Battlefront 2 is an immensely fun game. While it doesn't necessarily compare to the first which was a bit better (sadly not on Steam), it is still a great experience. However, there are plenty of things like custom maps, unofficial patches, and conversion mods which can make it 10x more fun than either vanilla game. The added element of space combat makes it all the more fun. Plenty of awards to grind for and collect to make yourself an unstoppable brute. One meh thing is that the hero meter is very annoying that slowly degrades and is vampirically recharged to keep heroes alive and they could have done a smidge better with the saber combat especially since something like Jedi Academy came out two years earlier.

Sadly, multiplayer has been disabled, but is still possible through some third party programs or patches that support player made servers. Destroying ships and blasting away pesky droids with a friend is always great.

One complaint is that the shooting isn't the greatest with the huge reticles, all-over-the-place AI, and the aiming and even blaster bolts can act wonky sometimes. It isn't absolutely insufferable, but it has room for improvement. Otherwise, lots of fun, campaign centered around the 501st clone regiment, galactic conquest mode, and instant action with all the great Star Wars locations from the water planet twelve parsecs outside the Rishi Maze to the most wretched hive of scum and villainy on Tatooine.

reviewText:
Probably in my top 10 games ever.

Im not even a huge star wars fan. I mean, I really like the original movies, and i like all of the lore and the deep history of the universe, but its not like im buying all of the games and books. I had this game for the PS2 a long time ago when my uncle bought it for me. I played it a good amount, but never really was a huge fan. A couple days ago I remembered it and bought it 5 minutes after. When I played it I remembered everything i like about it. This is by far the best star wars game ever. The concept was so fresh and new for a star wars game, instead of being a jedi or a huge character for the movie, you play as one of the soldiers in the large scale battles of the 6 films. Each location is different and most of them are a lot of fun, the gameplay is an absolute blast, the heroes and jedi you can play as are awesome, i can go on and on about why this game is so good. So if you remember playing this game when you were younger, i strongly reccomend buying it. You wont regret it. Its great. 10/10. Yee haw.


(P.S. I know that the EA game isnt going to be as good as the original, but could it at least be good and not filled with DLC? Could you do at least that EA? Please?)

reviewText:
Star Wars Battlefront 2 is one of the best games out there. Even better that the first one. It adds up more vehicles, classes and you can also play as a Hero (Jedi, Sith, Bounty Hunter etc.)! The graphics are amazing considering the time that the game came out.
I love this game so much, I still have and play the PS2, XBOX and PSP versions of the game.
Having a huge variety of maps, the fun never ends, you can test your skills in instant action with four game modes (conques, ctf, heroes vs villians and assault),then you can conquer the galaxy in Galactic Conquest mode choosing from four (4) factions (Rebels vs Empire and CIS vs Republic).
The maps are amazing, really big, it's a war game afterall. You also have the ability to play space battles, something that the first game lacked (and the newest one...), your objective is to destroy the enemy capital ship!
But no, that's not all. Download mods and or maps (prefered) in which you play space to ground on the maps the game already has or new maps that fans made!
People still play the game online so it's not dead! This is hands down one of the best, if not the best Star Wars game!
There are some glitches but not game breaking. Some characters are over-powered but they can be defeated if you know how to play well of course! The developers did a great job, but there are some stuff they could have added such as space to ground battles and the ability to escape enemy capital ships with an escape pod just like Elite Squadron.
Other than that Star Wars Battlefront 2 is an amazing game and you should have it in your game library!

9/10

reviewText:
Star Wars - Battlefront II is a third person shooter by LucasArts that puts you in the shoes of a common trooper or a droid while you reenact the greatest battle of the six Star Wars movies.You can play as the armies of the Republic, the CIS, the Empire and the Rebels, since the game covers both the Clone Wars and the Galactic Civil War eras from the Star Wars canon.
Battlefront II spots a single player campaign revolving around a legion of elite clone soldiers, the 501st, as they serve the Republic during the Clone Wars during the last days of the democracy to later become one of the most feared army of the new Galactic Empire. The campaign takes place in several maps also available in multiplayer, but also tasks the player to complete several kinds of objective (like capturing a command post, destroying a target or defeat an enemy hero), so playing through the various missions feels like an unique experience and worth of a try.
Battlefront II also introduces new maps where space battle take place: you can play as either a pilot or a marine from your faction, grab a ship (which can be either a heavy bombardier or a fast fighter) and try to severely damage the enemy fleet by either destroying its fighters or cripple its main ship either from the outside or the inside. While space battles always follow a strick formula with little room for alternative strategies, they are a welcome addition nevertheless.
One of the major improvement from the original game in the sequel is about the hero units: while in Battlefront they weren't playable, the second game allows you to take direct control of them, albeit for a short time (which you can increase by killing enemies). You can play as both Sith and Jedi and scoundrels and bounty hunters from the two eras, each with his/her own weapons and powers.
Another single player mode you can access in Battlefront II is the galactic conquest scenario: after choosing one of the four faction you are tasked to bring it to victory over its rival army and take absolute control of the galaxy. You have to move your army on a map of the galaxy and plan your attacks carefully. Winning confrontations grants you credits that can be used to purchase bonuses that can be activated for a single battle to enhance your armies (the bacta tanks perk will give your soldiers regenerating health, for instance).
The multiplayer mode returns in Battlefront II in full force, offering several traditional game modes like capture the flag or control point captures or hunt on a pletora of new maps. It's also worth mentioning that the game has a very dedicated modding community always redy to develop new maps from different eras of the Star Wars canon (the Old Republic, for instance) or add new heroic or normal units per factions.
Star Wars - Battlefront II is often labelled as one of the best games with a Star Wars license and I tend to agree, due to the very interesting and catchy gameplay and the excellent use of the series' canonic materials

reviewText: It's truly amazing, that even with Gamespy's shutdown and EA releasing a polished turd, Star Wars Battlefront 2's online community is still as strong as ever.  Just download GameRanger and create a profile!  There are dozens of servers you can join or you can even host your own!  By far the best Battlefront, best Star Wars game, and my personal favorite game of all time.  And the best part about all this is.....  It's not $70!  I absolutely recommend this game and it deserves an 11/10.\n\nGameranger can be downloaded at:  https://www.gameranger.com/

reviewText:
If you are happened upon this game while browsing for the 2015 'Battlefront' and accidentally scrolled down to the reviews, and my review gets to the top, then don't buy 'Battlefront' 2015. Better coombat, more class options, more maps, more players on said maps, mods, brilliant gameplay etc.

Or if, you know, you liek pwetty gwafix and noizes, get 'Battlefront' 2015.

reviewText:
There isn't much to say, just... Well, this game beats most new games.

Not only is this just plain old fun, but the glitches are halerious! Time it right and you can land your star fighter (or another ship) through the force field... Then jump out and walk aroun ON TOP OF YOUR SHIP!!!
Another time I was stuck on the final mission; Hoth. It was easy enough getting to the enemy hanger but taking it was impossible. I worked out two ways of taking it: 1. Run in, steal a rebel snow speader, fly out, turn around, fly in and let loose the blasters! 2. A bit more buggy but still a good technique. I was trying to use my walker (At-Rt, I believe) to gun through the doorway because it was about a centimeter to big... But when you sprint with it, your head bobs down low enough to slip through! Once again, I let loose my blasters.
10 years of games and this is still one of the best.

reviewText: Star Wars Battlefront II (SWBFii) has it all for the Star Wars fan who wants to travel and battle through the universe. You'll find virtually every key clash from all six Star Warsmovies, from the Battle of Geonosis to the Battle of Hoth—24 in all. Many are from Episode III: Revenge of the Sith, including fights on volcanic Mustafar, conflicts on the sinkhole planet of Utapau, and the hectic space battle above Coruscant. Classic movie moments complete the experience as gamers battle within the Death Star, Princess Leia's blockade runner, and the Tantive IV (as seen at the beginning of Episode IV: A New Hope, ), as well as on the swampy planet of Dagobah).
